p: A third group of mathematical models has explored networks. They do not assume that the population is homogeneously mixed. Instead, they consider the relative location of each individual (a ‘node’ or vertex, which may be represented by a circle or point), and contacts between individuals (‘links’ or ‘edges’, e.g., a line that connects two nodes [20]– [24]). While network models are usually labeled ‘spatial’, typically, they lack geographic data [25].
